presentation.title: How APIs Change Software Development
presentation.toc: Software engineering and development are changing because IT architecture and landscapes are changing. It used to be the case that organizations were building systems, and the main focus was on integration and how to maintain and evolve those systems. Microservices and other trends show us that this picture is changing: Now it is more about self-contained and independently deployable components which are part of an ecosystem of communicating components. The "glue" in this ecosystem are APIs, which are the only way how these components communicate. How does this shift in architecture affect software design and development? In this presentation we specifically look at how APIs affect both how components provide services, and how they consume them. The goal of this presentation is to allow software developers to better understand how APIs are an essential part of this rather fundamental shift in IT architecture.

presentation.title:
What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset
presentation.toc: APIs are very popular nowadays and very likely will only become more popular in the future. After all, they are the glue that hold digital building blocks together, and digitalization isn't going anywhere anytime soon. But this also means that APIs will become more ubiquitous, that there will be more APIs to manage within and across organizations, and the API space will become more dynamic and more diverse. As a result, API landscapes may start to resemble the Web in terms of scale, diversity, and complexity. It thus may be a good approach to think about what the solution to a given API problem looks like in the Web space. In this presentation, we look at a variety of topics from this perspective and we learn to approach API problems with a webby mindset. Don't hold yourself back by thinking that "APIs are different", instead start thinking "What Would the Web Do?"

a.title: Hypermedia APIs: What are they and what can they do for you?

div.style: float : left ; width : 65% ; object-fit : contain ; margin : 0% 2% 4% 4% ;

iframe.style: border: 0 ; top: 0 ; left: 0 ; width: 100% ; height: 100% ; position: absolute;

ul.li: Hypermedia combines state representation and possible further interactions
Resource state allows clients to understand the current content
Links allow clients to learn about the possible next steps
Clients select and follow a link based on their application goals
Workflows are represented by providing navigation options (affordances)
Making it easier for clients to be driven by available options
Seamless fabric of navigation across individual APIs
Extensibility generally is a good idea for APIs
Eliminates or reduces the need to do potentially expensive versioning
Hypermedia representations by definition combine data and control elements
Data extensibility results in the usual benefits of allowing representations to evolve
Control extensibility results in the ability to add new workflow paths
Hypermedia-based evolution has many patterns to choose from
Incremental additions can show up as new links in extension slots
Complete new APIs can be advertised as new start resources in home documents

a.title: API Versioning: Managing APIs over Time the Web Way

div.style: float : left ; width : 65% ; object-fit : contain ; margin : 0% 2% 4% 4% ;

iframe.style: border: 0 ; top: 0 ; left: 0 ; width: 100% ; height: 100% ; position: absolute;

ul.li: The core of the API allows clients to have meaningful interactions
The starting point of an API should be meaningful and complete
The core of the API is robust over time
Anything that is added to the core does not change the core semantics
Anything that is not part of the core can be safely ignored
mustIgnore semantics allow safe interactions beyond closely coordinated groups
APIs should be clear about where extensions are allowed
API metamodels often decide where (potential) extension points are
API schemas/definitions should further narrow down where extensions are allowed
API tests can make sure that the extension points are properly implemented
Extensions in allowed places are ignored and tests should succeed
Extensions in other places should raise errors about malformed content
Extensions are well-defined and their handling is well-defined as well
Extension points make it clear where to expect extensions
Processing models make it clear what to do with extensions
mustIgnore is a popular and good choice for extension processing
Some formats allow extensions to declare their processing model (such as mustUnderstand)
HTML has a rule of ignoring unknown elements but processing their content
How to learn about extensions is a different matter

a.title: What is a Platform? And what can API Platforms learn from the Web?

div.style: float : left ; width : 65% ; object-fit : contain ; margin : 0% 2% 4% 4% ;

iframe.style: border: 0 ; top: 0 ; left: 0 ; width: 100% ; height: 100% ; position: absolute;

ul.li: What a platform is:
Generating value by facilitating exchanges/interactions between groups
Creating networks of users and resources that can be accessed on-demand
Using the network effect to grow communities and markets
Creating value by reducing transaction costs and/or by externalizing innovation
What a platform is not:
It is not just technology, it is the business model enabled by technology
It is not a linear business model with unidirectional value chains
It is not (completely) owning the means of production
Platforms enable organizations to create and deliver value
Technology can be both limiting and enabling
Limiting when creation/delivery seems to be too slow/costly
Enabling when digitalization opens new opportunities
Business can be both limiting and enabling
Limiting when business demands are not aligned with technology
Enabling when technology is used to create/deliver value faster
Any platform must make sure to align technology and business
